intro: Agalinis purpurea var. racemulosa, commonly known as the purple false foxglove, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its tall, erect stems and clusters of showy, tubular flowers. The plant typically blooms in late spring to early summer, producing vibrant purple to pink flowers that attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. It thrives in moist, sunny habitats like wetlands and prairies, and it often grows in colonies. The leaves are lance-shaped and arranged oppositely along the stem, contributing to its ornamental appeal.
